I play catan in real life all the time. LIKE... ALL THE TIME. I am not terrible at this game, at the least I can hold my own.  THIS GAME IS IMPOSSIBLE.  I have set everyone to the easiest and I still lose in C&K and occasionally in a normal game. every single game the two big numbers I am not on (Usually an 11 or a 3) get consistently rolled. I get it, its random, but how random?  I can tell I am on easy because the computer doesn't go in for the kill when it should. So why can't I get a small streak of probable numbers? Why do the computers trade with each other so much? ESPECIALLY IN THE END! One traded and one the game!  I just really hate that I can't under any circumstance beat a C&K campaign.

Good game, no bugs that I've seen, wish there were more scenarios.

AI and gameplay mechanics are designed to skew the game. Sometimes this works for you and sometimes it works against you, but it often makes for very lopsided games. A bizarrely high number of repeat rolls on 2's and 12's. Game consistently rolls 3-4 times more of a given number than the odds would allow. The AI's ability to steal cards they aren't able to trade from you is extraordinary regardless of how many cards you have in hand. Inability to undo an action in inexcusable for a game that is typically played on a very small screen. AI is also very poor at recognizing the winning player leading to the computers piling on you when they are about to be beaten by AI. I love Catan, but the number of statistical anomalies makes this version very frustrating and at times infuriating. Get the Xbox or PC version instead.

Other than that, it's quite true to the "analog" experience, and if you want to practice with bots or find yourself with a Catan buddy but without a board, it's well worth the $4.

I've played the ipad version, and think the random number complaints are overblown... but the AI could also use improvement.  Or it could support network play, and I wouldn't need AI improvement.  Edit: The UI issues were fixed, albeit in a weird and silly way.  So +3 stars because it's now playable.  Still no network play.

As a huge Catan fan I'm pretty disappointed I paid for this. Weird bugs are everywhere (got caught watching a trade that would go back and forth infinitely, some trades don't go through even though you agreed to them, etc.), and apparently the developers of this app thought it appropriate to change some rules entirely (you are not allowed to build settlements in the middle of someone else's road the last time I checked). If it was free, I would probably give it a 3 star review, and that's being forgiving.

Update: does not work on my galaxy tab 10.1. Must perform hard reset.  First of all, thank you USM for finally pushing out the high definition graphics.   That said, I only have one tiff with the game: I would love to freely view the game map as I am considering a trade.   Being able to do this is a huge part of the game. Resource values are relative to each individual player. What is common for one player may be rare for another. Also, settlement positions and the current goal of the players in your region also dictate who and what you want to trade with. Even if two players make the same offer, I may prefer one over the other.  Maybe you could implement some kind of behavior where I may slide the trade window down and then navigate the map. I may then slide the trade window up and restore focus to the trade.   I see that I may already (sort of) navigate the map within the narrow margin at the upper most portion of my screen. I just ask for the ability to see more of the map while trading.     Thank you for considering this!

This is quite possibly the best four dollars I've ever spent.  I played for over 100 hours, first beating each board in the custom game, then completing the campaign.  (I recommend you do it this way because you'll probably be less likely to want to play the custom games after beating the campaign.)    The game has a easily accessible save and quit options, making it great to play when you're commuting or when you just have a few minutes here and there.  Graphics are good, gameplay is smooth, and the update fixes my issues with resolution on Samsung Galaxy SIII (I orginally played on Droid X, which looked great.)    Seafarers expansion was worth it; I look forward to playing Cities and Knights!

I also bought the Cities and Knights expansion which adds another layer of depth (and another layer of frustration).  I would give it 5 stars if there were more options to enable, disable, or alter rules. Personally, I'd like to control these rules: Disable robber. Disable city/settlement limits. Disable resource depletion (Eg. always pick a random value) - depletion is the only thing stopping me from getting Seafarers. Disable specific progress cards, or even build your own deck list  I'd also like to be able to play 2 player. Or even 1 player just for testing and messing around.

This conversion of the Catan board game is plagued with issues. Though slick, it's unneccessarily confusing and difficult to play. It relies on confusing unlabeled menu icons. It is not designed for the colorblind. Constant animation of the game tiles detracts from the board and drains the battery unneccessarily. There's no way to see which number the robber covers, or to consult the board during opponents trade turns, or to quit or restart during the board setup phase. Needs improvement.

UPDATE: Icons are now sized correctly in the latest version. However there seems to be a cache corruption issue on the Xoom. The biggest problem with this game is the dice rolling algorithm. To make the game harder, the dice rolls come out to favour your opponents. In the original version of this game, you could force the dice rolls to be properly distributed, but in the latest version you can't.   This game is a bit expensive for an Android title. I guess this is due to the popularity of the physical board game. Having the seafarers expansion teased & costing more than I paid for the base game though is a slap in the face. UPDATE: Graphics scaling has been fixed. This game is now pure awesomeness.  This app has so much promise, but the problems nearly ruin it. I installed it on a 7" tablet (1024x600), and I'm experiencing two major problems:  1. Button clicks often do not register. This can actually make you lose a game.  2. The scaling of the text and graphics (aside from the board, which can be zoomed) is terrible. The text is tiny and the little icons for resources are almost impossible to make out. It's hard to tell whose turn it is, or which player is me. The colors for the roads and settlements are seriously difficult for a color-blind person to differentiate.  If these two problems were fixed, it would be a great game. One of the coolest concepts is that the use of language is almost absent during gameplay.  One recommendation I'd make as a beginning player: It would be awesome to have a button that showed a summary of the previous turn. Who got what, who traded what, who put what where. Sometimes things move so quickly that I'm not sure what changed.

I love the Settlers of Catan board game, so I had high hopes for this app, but it just doesn't cut the mustard.  There are a lot of user interface issues, for example: text is unreadably small on both my Galaxy Nexus and Nexus 7, resource dragging/dropping is really glitchy, it takes way too many taps to start a game, scrolling/panning doesn't quite work right, etc.   Most maddening is the computer player artificial intelligence though.  Simply, it's not very good, which can make gameplay exceedingly frustrating at first (while you boggle at its illogical moves) and boring later on (after you learn its quirks and are able to exploit them).  Trading and robber placement algorithms in particular seem very primitive.  I'm a software engineer myself, so I know getting this stuff right isn't easy, but at the end of the day it's still not good enough.  I would not recommend purchasing this app if you plan to play against the computer, and if you intend to play pass-along style with friends, you're probably better off buying one of the physical portable editions of the game. Used it on my Galaxy Tab 10.1, tried on my Nexus, but too small of course. With a tablet the icons are perfectly sized, although I wish it would rotate (charger cable is on the bottom of the device).  The game is a bit glitchy, every once in a while it will freeze when loading a scenario, but haven't noticed any other glitches. I think people are exaggerating the dice issues. I know that digital dice are questionable, and I've had a few times where 3's or 11's came up ridiculously often, but the game shows you overall dice stats afterwards, and overall they are close to statistical norms.   The AI is a bit problematic, it is programmed to rob like crazy when you are in the lead at all, and unfortunately it still will occasionally steal from you when you aren't in the lead. It's particularly annoying when you are in the lead due to Victory Points not associated with settlements or cities, such as bonuses for scenario objectives or longest road, and the AI still continuously robs you instead of better off players (from a resource standpoint). It also trades weird, and once you get used to how the AI plays, it becomes rather easy.  Looking forward to expansions/updates

One common example is for the robber to be placed on on your 3 or 11 hex, ignoring your juicy 6, only to have that low-ranked number rolled next. It is rare an AI can match a human in games of this nature. This app is designed to try to close the gap by having the AI players be able to throw numbers that see to it you're blocked out.   Are both computers sitting on the 10s? Expect to see a massive spike in 10s on the bell curve. Worse, the system is aware of what it's doing and tries to cover for it. If you're on a 6 and the computer is on the other, as soon as they drop the robber on your space expect a wave of 6 rolls to even out the bell. There will be several games where the AIs gang up to rob you blind, regardless if you're in the lead or not. When it comes time to pull Dev cards, expect to pull nothing but Knights while the monopoly and victory point cards go to the AIs.  This becomes doubly frustrating as you have to beat the AIs in campaign mode to unlock some of the maps for free play. Logically you'll succeed eventually, but not before many hours of frustration at being cheated out of the game.  Beyond the cheats on the Dev cards and the dice this is a accurate game of Catan. The game would be well served to remove these cheats and add a challenge mode that gives the computer a resource lead instead.

Good enough to get my mobile Catan fix, but plenty of problems:  <1> *massive* battery hog, <2> doesn't actually shut down on exit (requiring manual stop / kill task from the task manager; wouldn't be as big an issue if #1 weren't also true),  <3> really cruddy gameplay workflow / UI.  Re <3> the game-play workflow is *way* too menu intensive. Want to buy a Dev card? Open the menu first, then the Dev card sub-menu, then buy the card.  Want to view your Dev cards? Re-open the menu, then the Dev card sub-menu, then scroll through several pages of the Dev card list. Ugh.  Want to build a road?  Open the menu first, then the building sub-menu, then buy the road.  Want to build 2 roads?  The menu closes after buying the first road, so repeat the entire process.  You get the idea.  PITA.  Other issues: can't view own Dev cards when prompted to play Knight.  Should show all Dev cards in one screen.  More issues, but I've run out of room.  Simpler, better UI:  if you have the resources to build a road, simply tap a valid location for a road.  If you have the resources to build a city, simply tap the settlement you want to upgrade. Etc.  Could be so much easier.

1. When playing the AI pay close attention to the # of dev cards your opponents purchase, carry, and play in each round, especially round 1.  On two occasions I've seen the AI players buy & play Dev Cards on the first round!!! 2. When you get ahead of AI, sevens rolled galore, so blatant to the point you can predict when a 7 will come up.  AI hits you with the robber every time, sometimes 2-3 times per turn, to drain you of cards to allow them to catch up. Then when AI players catch up or surpass, no 7s... Check dice stats to see. It sometimes feels like I only bother to play anymore, to see if I can beat the AI regardless of the bias.

Please, please fix the algorithm. While I enjoy the board game immensely, I'm certain I'll destroy my Droid tablet out of shear frustration with this game!!!! The computers gain up on you, the dice never play your numbers, and you can count on having resources stolen every match. Nothing like the board version. Don't waste your money!

I see a lot of complaints about the UI already so I'm going to focus and expand on the horrible cheating AI. My major complaint is how all difficulty and challenge from the game seems to only come from the AI being able to cheat. I've had one truly enjoyable game where the AI didn't feel like it was cheating, and I actually lost that game too. Most the time the AI rolls the robber and alternates it between your most common resource numbers, even when it does not benefit itself but will benefit one of the other AI characters, that most often is in the lead.  Also if you get a victory point card or two that put you in the lead, the AI knows it and gangs up on you and is much more ruthless when you're in the lead. Yet if the AI has victory point card, you do not know this till they pull out a surprise win. Also the AI seems to get development cards constantly, if your strategy is to get largest army, don't bother; the AI will get somewhere around 4-8 knight cards played within the first 6-10 turns. Best to focus on longest road and expanding, use knight cards purely for defense because you will be doing so a lot.  There is more but I'll just say this: the game NEEDS multi-player!

The text and icons on my nexus are so tiny I can't make a single thing out and can't play it because of this. Its like it thinks my phone is the size of a tablet... as far as I'm concerned it may as well be crashing on startup...
This COULD be a fantastic implementation of Catan, were it not plagued by horribly small text and icons. I spend more time TRYING to tap an icon than I do playing the actual game.

I'm new to android (catan itself is old hat for me), only having gotten my galaxy s2 within the last few months, but years and years ago I was a pda enthusiast, and gaming was always my focus.  This is a polished game, and if you're perfectly happy playing versus AI or in hotseat single-unit passaround mode, then by all means consider that I gave it 5 stars.  However, given what can be accomplished on these fantastic little devices, and the price tag, online play should've been an update by now.  Granted, developers claim that it's on its way, but finding further info on that is a chore so far.  Stay tuned to this app...if they update in the multiplayer, it'll be more than worth the price.

I thought this would be fun, like the real version, but I just played against seven different "people"that came with the game for two hours and every single development card and every single seven was used to move the robber back and fourth on my pieces and mine alone (if you've played the real game you get this). I was unable to ever build it but anything because I never got any cards. This was an awful waste of four bucks

I want to give this version of the game a five star, but it lacks online multiplayer, and I really feel it deserves a three star given that it is definitely an unfair balance when you're in the lead and the sevens start to roll uncontrollably and the AI are pitted against you. (Passing up on trading 2 wheat and 2 brick for one measley wood just 'cause I'm in the lead and you're designed to make it difficult? Any human player would gladly take four cards of any kind. Money is money, and I wish you could have that human element to work with in your strategy.)  But I give it a four. It's the classic addictive formula we all know and love, and it certainly satisfies the urge when it comes time to pick up and try the various different scenarios that keep the gameplay fresh and engaging. But holy hell, it sure does seem like the rolls suddenly are out to get me sometimes, but in all honestly, I've been very aware of the times when five rolls straight got me just what I needed to win a match.  In terms of it's technical performance, it's graphics are quick, snappy, clean, readable, and without glitch as far as I've seen on the Galaxy S II.   Add online multiplayer please! Just do it!

This is easily the worst mobile game I've ever played. Buggy, horrible GUI, and computer players definitely gang up on you. There isn't even that much in the game, you have to but all the extra content. If I could get my money back I would.

You can't really go wrong with Catan, since the game mechanics are already well established, so expect a well balanced and enjoyable game. On the other hand, the visuals scale horribly to tablet, with icons that are too small to be usable. Switching from stretch to zoom makes it playable, but it comes at the cost of sharpness. I'll also echo the common grievance of AI stinginess when it comes to trading. For a game that is already relatively pricey, the added cost for the expansion is a bit hard to swallow.

I bought this mainly because I just bought the boardgame and figured this would help me get the strategy going in my head.  Gotta say, the boardgame is VASTLY superior. Playing against other people means you can actually trade! The AI is allied with each other just to prevent you from getting anything. My last game, I had a settlement on a wood 2:1 harbor and another settlement on a forest hex with an 8 chit on it. Guess how many 8s were rolled after I built that settlement? Also, I had another settlement on a clay hex with a 6 chit and many 6s only seemed to be rolled when the robber was on that hex. Cheap! I may have to go with the event card option now.  However, this app has vastly improved my understanding of what's going on in the boardgame quickly (due to being able to play by myself anytime) and therefore I give it a 4 for doing what I needed it to do. However, if I was rating it based off itself as a replacement to the boardgame, it gets a 3. It's fun and I like playing it but the cheapness is aggravating.  Not buying the seafarers expansion, but I would buy Cities and Knights in a heartbeat.

The UI is designed incredibly well, making the game fast and fun; however, its implementation on the Galaxy Nexus (720p) is terrible.  Some elements, such as the game board, scale quite nicely - although they get pixelated, they're very easy to read and interact with.  Some other elements don't, and that's where the game's greatness becomes overshadowed by poor optimization.  The start game menu, and the really nifty 5-item in-game menu don't scale.  The buttons become exceptionally hard to press, which quickly frustrate me to the point of not wanting to play a game - especially in public, cuz I don't want to look like a blind nubby-fingered fool when using my phone three inches from my face and repeatedly hammering on the same button with no effect.  A fairly simple rework would fix this, and quickly/easily turn it to a 5* app. (I understand from elsewhere that a tablet version is on the way.  I hope that the tablet-centered updates affect those of us using hi-res phones.)

I can't read anything and playing the game is nearly impossible because the buttons are so tiny. I don't see any options for increasing font or button size. The seafarers expansion, if you are curious, is 3.99 usd in-game. This app has genuinely surprised me. I was expecting a cheap, rushed port of the game, but literally all elements of the game are present, and the rules from the rule book for the physical version have been fully integrated. The AI is intelligent, and there are noticeably different playing styles between the characters. The wide selection of game modes is also great, though it is a little disappointing that the 'Seafarers' expansion cannot be bought directly from the Market - it must be downloaded from the in-game app store, for the same price as the original version.  However, this is only a minor quibble. The game looks great, the animations are slick, the characters are funny and often deliver tongue-in-cheek lines, and the graphics are faithful to the original hex design. All in all, a faithful and extremely addictive version of Catan.

I like this game a lot, and it is playable in it's current state.  However, there are a lot of bugs.  The zoom buttons are not properly sized and they cover the dice.  Whenever you end your turn, you can see the next players resources before they start their turn.  If you have victory points, you can see those counted in the total score when you view the ranking on the stats page.  Also, none of the touch locations match up when played on a tablet.  A tablet optimized version would be awesome to play on.

This is a pretty faithful implementation of the board game. When it works, it plays quickly and smoothly. And, most importantly, it crashes and reboots my phone 3/4 of the time I play. I have a Droid X running the most recently patched version of Gingerbread. Since it is a fairly large game, good luck downloading and playing it enough for a valid test run in the allowed 15 mins.
